Barcelona (non-stop) S$30.84 S$30.84 🇯🇵 Sapporo S$29.74 S$29.74 🇮🇳 Delhi S$29.19 S$29.19 🇯🇵 Fukuoka S$29.08 S$29.08 🇮🇳 Chennai S$28.77 S$28.77 🇮🇳 Mumbai S$28.60 S$28.60 🇻🇳 Da Nang S$28.42 S$28.42 🇻🇳 Ho Chi Minh S$28.42 S$28.42 🇮🇳 Kochi S$27.70 S$27.70 🇲🇾 Kuala Lumpur S$26.01 S$26.01 🇺🇸 Los Angeles (via NRT) S$23.11 S$23.11 🇵🇭 Cebu S$22.46 S$22.46 🇰🇷 Seoul S$21.29 S$21.29 🇵🇭 Manila S$20.79 S$20.79 🇮🇩 Jakarta S$20.40 S$20.40 🇮🇩 Medan S$20.40 S$20.40 🇹🇼 Taipei S$20.36 S$20.36 🇲🇾 Penang S$18.72 S$18.72 🇮🇩 Bali S$18.38 S$18.38 🇮🇩 Surabaya S$17.61 S$17.61 🇰🇷 Busan S$16.86 S$16.86 🇨🇳 Beijing S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Chengdu S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Chongqing S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Xiamen S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Shanghai S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Guangzhou S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Shenzhen S$16.49 S$16.49 🇧🇳 Brunei S$12.00 S$12.00 🇺🇸 New York (non-stop) S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 Los Angeles (non-stop) S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 San Francisco S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 Seattle S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 Newark S$7.19 N/A* Based on exchange rates as of 26 December 2025.

*SIA does not actually offer Economy Class on this flight (the A350-900ULR has no Economy Class section), but if it existed, you would pay S$7.19 too

Within the SIA route network, the most expensive airport taxes on average are from Europe, while the USA, perhaps surprisingly, has the lowest. Of course, there can be large variations within regions, as our earlier example of London and Barcelona showed.

Region Min. Max. ↓ Avg. Europe S$30.84 S$476.42 S$167.49 Australia & NZ S$39.71 S$125.81 S$88.65 South Asia S$27.70 S$308.07 S$67.23 MENA S$43.13 S$45.44 S$43.90 Southeast Asia S$12.00 S$44.93 S$27.00 North Asia S$16.49 S$70.16 S$26.03 USA S$7.19 S$37.61 S$13.81

No prizes for guessing that the most expensive airports to fly from are based in the UK, thanks to APD!

Most Expensive Airports Least Expensive Airports 1. 🇬🇧 London Heathrow (S$476.42)

2. 🇬🇧 Manchester (S$431.83)

3. 🇬🇧 London Gatwick (S$423.69) 1. 🇺🇸 All USA airports (S$7.19)

2. 🇧🇳 Brunei (S$12)

3. 🇨🇳 All China airports (S$16.49) *Based on Business Class travel, though the order would look no different if we used Economy Class

A couple of points to note.

Taxes are usually the same regardless of cabin

Generally speaking, you will pay the same airport taxes and fees regardless of cabin.

However, exceptions apply for Hong Kong, France, the Maldives and the UK.

Y PY J F London (Heathrow) £144.79 £274.79 London (Gatwick) £114.38 £244.38 Manchester £119.07 £249.07 Paris €96.35 €176.35 Hong Kong HKD 355 HKD 425 Maldives US$100 US$240 US$480

In the UK, the Air Passenger Duty (APD) adds a significant chunk to the cost of plane tickets. For long-haul international flights, you’ll have to pay £94 in Economy, and £224 in Premium Economy, Business and First Class, on top of the other charges imposed by the airport.

In France, the Air Passenger Solidarity Tax is charged at €40 for Economy and Premium Economy passengers, and €120 for Business and First Class passengers.

In Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Airport Construction Fee payable on flights to Singapore is charged at HKD 90 for Economy and Premium Economy Class passengers, and HKD 160 for Business and First Class passengers.

And in the Maldives, the Airport Service Charge and Airport Development Fee were recently hiked to US$100 for Economy and Premium Economy Class passengers, US$240 for Business Class passengers, and US$480 for First Class passengers (good thing Singapore Airlines doesn’t offer First Class to the Maldives!).

Incidentally, Singapore will soon join the ranks of countries with differentiated airport taxes by cabin class, when it introduces the Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Levy from October 2026. This is a “green tax” which ranges from S$1 to S$41.60, depending on cabin and class of travel.

Economy & Premium Economy Business & First Band 1

Southeast Asia S$1 S$4 Band 2

Northeast Asia, South Asia, Australia, Papua New Guinea S$2.80 S$11.20 Band 3

Africa, Central and West Asia, Europe, Middle East, Pacific Islands, New Zealand S$6.40 S$25.60 Band 4

Americas S$10.40 S$41.60

Singapore flights to be hit by sustainable aviation fuel levy from October 2026

Stopovers can add to costs

A stopover may result in higher taxes than a non-stop flight, because of the additional fees charged by the transit airport. For example, flying non-stop to Singapore from New York JFK costs US$5.60, increasing to US$29.30 if a stopover in Frankfurt is added.

Non-stop One stop New York JFK US$5.60 US$29.30

(via FRA) Barcelona €20.39 €20.39

(via MXP) Los Angeles US$5.60 US$18

(via NRT)

However, this may not always be the case. You will pay the same €20.39 when you fly from Barcelona, whether you take the non-stop or one-stop flight (via Milan).

Southeast Asia

Airport Business Economy 🇰🇭 Siem Reap S$44.93 S$44.93 🇰🇭 Phnom Penh S$44.93 S$44.93 🇲🇲 Yangon S$36.26 S$36.26 🇻🇳 Hanoi S$34.86 S$34.86 🇹🇭 Bangkok S$32.23 S$32.23 🇹🇭 Phuket S$32.23 S$32.23 🇻🇳 Da Nang S$28.42 S$28.42 🇻🇳 Ho Chi Minh S$28.42 S$28.42 🇲🇾 Kuala Lumpur S$26.01 S$26.01 🇵🇭 Cebu S$22.46 S$22.46 🇵🇭 Manila S$20.79 S$20.79 🇮🇩 Jakarta S$20.40 S$20.40 🇮🇩 Medan S$20.40 S$20.40 🇲🇾 Penang S$18.72 S$18.72 🇮🇩 Bali S$18.38 S$18.38 🇮🇩 Surabaya S$17.61 S$17.61 🇧🇳 Brunei S$12.00 S$12.00

Airport taxes within the region are generally low and below S$45, making Singapore’s S$65.20 — which will soon increase further — a relative outlier. Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines are on the lower end, while Cambodia, Hanoi and Myanmar are relatively more expensive.

From North Asia

Airport Business Economy 🇭🇰 Hong Kong S$70.16 S$58.61 🇯🇵 Osaka S$38.14 S$38.14 🇯🇵 Nagoya S$34.60 S$34.60 🇯🇵 Tokyo (Narita) S$34.27 S$34.27 🇯🇵 Tokyo (Haneda) S$32.54 S$32.54 🇯🇵 Sapporo S$29.74 S$29.74 🇯🇵 Fukuoka S$29.08 S$29.08 🇰🇷 Seoul S$21.29 S$21.29 🇹🇼 Taipei S$20.36 S$20.36 🇰🇷 Busan S$16.86 S$16.86 🇨🇳 Beijing S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Chengdu S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Chongqing S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Xiamen S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Shanghai S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Guangzhou S$16.49 S$16.49 🇨🇳 Shenzhen S$16.49 S$16.49

Hong Kong is the priciest airport in North Asia to fly from, particularly if you’re in First or Business Class. Otherwise, the taxes in this region are fairly modest and below S$50. Japan ranges from ~S$30-40, significantly lower than the last time I compiled these figures in 2019 owing to the depreciation of the JPY.

Regardless of which airport in mainland China you fly from, you’ll pay a standard CNY90 departure tax.

From South Asia

Airport Business Economy 🇲🇻 Male S$308.07 S$128.36 🇧🇩 Dhaka S$104.01 S$104.01 🇱🇰 Colombo S$78.00 S$78.00 🇮🇳 Hyderabad S$43.49 S$43.49 🇮🇳 Bengaluru S$43.35 S$43.35 🇮🇳 Kolkata S$40.24 S$40.24 🇮🇳 Ahmedabad S$38.29 S$38.29 🇳🇵 Kathmandu S$37.10 S$37.10 🇮🇳 Delhi S$29.19 S$29.19 🇮🇳 Chennai S$28.77 S$28.77 🇮🇳 Mumbai S$28.60 S$28.60 🇮🇳 Kochi S$27.70 S$27.70

Within South Asia, the Maldives takes the cake as the most expensive airport to fly from, especially if you’re in a premium cabin. The recent hikes in airport taxes, Green Tax and T-GST have made this already expensive destination even pricier to visit, and I can’t say I’m itching to return.

This is also a good time to remember that what you pay for is not necessarily what you get. Delhi’s modernised airport is generally well-regarded (Best Airport in India & South Asia according to Skytrax, if that means anything to you), and charges just under S$30 worth of taxes. Meanwhile, Dhaka charges S$104, and let’s just say the reviews are mixed (thankfully, a new terminal is supposedly opening soon).

From MENA

Airport Business Economy 🇦🇪 Dubai S$45.44 S$45.44 🇿🇦 Cape Town (via JNB) S$43.13 S$43.13 🇿🇦 Johannesburg S$43.13 S$43.13

There isn’t a lot of variability within the MENA region, with Dubai, Cape Town and Johannesburg all attracting roughly the same taxes.

From Australia & New Zealand

Airport Business Economy 🇦🇺 Darwin S$125.81 S$125.81 🇦🇺 Adelaide S$106.54 S$106.54 🇦🇺 Cairns S$100.77 S$100.77 🇦🇺 Sydney S$100.14 S$100.14 🇦🇺 Melbourne S$98.50 S$98.50 🇦🇺 Brisbane S$97.04 S$97.04 🇦🇺 Perth S$82.87 S$82.87 🇳🇿 Auckland S$46.43 S$46.43 🇳🇿 Christchurch S$39.71 S$39.71

Airport taxes are significantly lower in New Zealand than Australia, but remember, New Zealand charges international arrivals an International Visitor Levy which costs NZ$100, on top of NZ$17 for an eTA!

Moreover, if you’re planning a trans-Tasman trip, you’ll still get hit with the full amount of airport taxes when flying between Australia and New Zealand, so there’s not much reason to reposition here for the purposes of cost savings alone.

Even within Australia, there can be significant variations in taxes. It costs S$82.87 to fly from Perth, compared to S$125.81 from Darwin, a 50% difference.

It’s worth noting that Australia is one of the few countries to charge an arrivals tax for incoming passengers, which will add an extra S$22.70 to S$38.70 to the cost of your flight from Singapore (more on this later).

From Europe

Airport Business Economy 🇬🇧 London Heathrow S$476.42 S$251.03 🇬🇧 Manchester S$431.83 S$206.44 🇬🇧 London Gatwick S$423.69 S$198.31 🇫🇷 Paris S$266.73 S$145.73 🇩🇪 Frankfurt S$192.93 S$192.93 🇩🇪 Munich S$166.83 S$166.83 🇳🇱 Amsterdam S$127.32 S$127.32 🇩🇰 Copenhagen S$112.98 S$112.98 🇧🇪 Brussels S$60.86 S$60.86 🇮🇹 Rome S$60.15 S$60.15 🇨🇭 Zurich S$57.01 S$57.01 🇮🇹 Milan S$39.19 S$39.19 🇹🇷 Istanbul S$34.66 S$34.66 🇪🇸 Barcelona (via MXP) S$30.84 S$30.84 🇪🇸 Barcelona (non-stop) S$30.84 S$30.84

Europe is a classic example of how repositioning can result in big savings. And unlike other regions, it can often make practical sense, since tourists frequently visit multiple countries on a single trip, and intra-Europe flights/train rides are relatively affordable.

We’ve already seen the big disparity between the UK and Spain, but other (relatively) low-cost places to originate from include Turkey, Italy and surprisingly, Switzerland. France, Germany, Netherlands and Denmark are significantly more expensive, so try to fly into these destinations rather than out of them.

From USA

Airport Business Economy 🇺🇸 New York (via FRA) S$37.61 S$37.61 🇺🇸 Los Angeles (via NRT) S$23.11 S$23.11 🇺🇸 New York (non-stop) S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 Los Angeles (non-stop) S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 San Francisco S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 Seattle S$7.19 S$7.19 🇺🇸 Newark S$7.19 $ –

There’s not a lot to say here, because the taxes for award tickets on non-stop flights from the USA are all the same at US$5.60 (S$7.19).

The only time a difference will arise is if you’re taking the one-stop flights from LAX (transit NRT) and JFK (transit FRA).

Using the ITA Matrix to check taxes

If you want to check the most up-to-date taxes for your flight, you can do so via the ITA Matrix. This flight search engine shows a detailed breakdown of the taxes on a ticket, and which country they’re attributable to.

Do note that you may see “carrier-imposed surcharge” (YR) on certain Singapore Airlines flights. This is not imposed on award redemptions, so you can safely ignore it.

Also, the taxes shown on the ITA Matrix will not be accurate for award tickets in the following countries.

Country Remarks 🇺🇸 United States

(Inbound) International Arrival Tax is not charged on award bookings

(Outbound) Passenger Facility Charge and International Departure Tax are not charged on award bookings

🇮🇳 India

(Outbound) India Goods and Services Tax is a percentage of ticket cost and varies by cabin. It is not charged on award bookings as no cash is paid towards the fare component

🇵🇭 Philippines

(Outbound) Philippines Travel Tax does not apply to foreign passport holders staying for <1 year (and selected other groups). ITA Matrix still displays this nonetheless

To see the actual taxes payable for these destinations, you’ll need to make a dummy booking on the Singapore Airlines website.

What about flying out of Singapore?

The standard taxes on a one-way award flight departing from Singapore are currently set at S$65.20. This will increase over the next few years to S$79.20 by April 2030, as part of plans to hike airline and passenger fees to finance a S$3 billion airport investment.

Passenger Service and Security Fee

(PSSF) Aviation Levy

(AL) Airport Development Levy

(ADL) Current

S$65.20

S$46.40 S$8 S$10.80 1 April 2026

S$65.20

S$46.40 S$8 S$10.80 1 April 2027

S$70.20

S$49.40

+S$3

S$10

+S$2

S$10.80 1 April 2028

S$73.20

S$52.40

+S$3

S$10 S$10.80 1 April 2029

S$76.20

S$55.40

+S$3

S$10 S$10.80 1 April 2030

S$79.20

S$58.40

+S$3

S$10 S$10.80

As mentioned earlier, there will also be the SAF levy to contend with for departures from October 2026, which will add an additional S$1 to S$41.60 to the figures above.

However, some countries also impose a tax on arriving passengers (because nothing says “welcome” like an arrival tax!). I’ve compiled these below for your reference.

Australia

Adelaide: S$29.70

Brisbane: S$36.90

Cairns: S$28.70

Darwin: S$38.70

Melbourne: S$29.10

Perth: S$22.70

Sydney: S$34.10

Myanmar: S$4.20

New Zealand

Christchurch: S$38.70

Auckland: S$46.70

Thailand: S$2.20

United Arab Emirates: S$1.80

United States: S$23.50

Conclusion

While award tickets save you from having to pay the airfare, you’re still on the hook for taxes and surcharges. Depending on where you’re flying from, these can either be a mild inconvenience, or reason enough to rejig your travel plans. Since most taxes are charged to departing passengers, the general rule should be that you fly into expensive airports, and out from cheaper ones.

Unfortunately, Singapore is fast becoming one of the more expensive airports to fly out from, not just within Southeast Asia, but within Asia Pacific in general. That will only get worse with the new SAF levy, especially for those travelling in premium cabins on long-haul flights.

title: How Traveling by Plane Will Change in 2026: A New Era of Smarter, Greener, and Faster Flights
description:
Air travel has always reflected the world’s changing priorities—speed, safety, comfort, and innovation.
As we move toward 2026, flying is set to undergo some of its most noticeable transformations in decades.
From biometric boarding to greener aircraft and redesigned cabins, the way passengers experience air travel is evolving rapidly.
In 2026, aircraft interiors will prioritize ergonomics, hygiene, and personalization.
In many ways, the future of air travel isn’t about machines—it’s about making flying work better for people.
text:
Air travel has always reflected the world’s changing priorities—speed, safety, comfort, and innovation. As we move toward 2026, flying is set to undergo some of its most noticeable transformations in decades. From biometric boarding to greener aircraft and redesigned cabins, the way passengers experience air travel is evolving rapidly. What once felt futuristic is becoming routine, and 2026 is expected to mark a turning point in how we fly.

Biometric Travel Will Become the New Normal

One of the biggest changes passengers will notice in 2026 is the widespread use of biometric identification. Facial recognition, already in use at select airports, will become standard for check-in, security, and boarding.

Instead of presenting passports and boarding passes multiple times, travelers will simply walk through checkpoints where cameras verify their identity in seconds. This will reduce queues, speed up boarding, and minimize physical contact—something travelers now value more than ever.

Airports aim to become “walk-through” experiences, where your face becomes your boarding pass.

Shorter Airport Wait Times Through AI and Automation

Artificial intelligence will play a major role in reducing delays. AI-powered systems will predict congestion, adjust staff deployment, and optimize flight schedules in real time. Security scanners will become smarter, requiring fewer manual checks while maintaining safety standards.

Robotic assistants may also appear more frequently—guiding passengers, answering questions, and even helping with luggage in large terminals. For frequent flyers, this means less stress and more predictability.

Greener Aircraft and Sustainable Flying

Sustainability is no longer optional for the aviation industry. By 2026, airlines are expected to significantly increase their use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), which can reduce carbon emissions by up to 80% compared to traditional jet fuel.

Newer aircraft models will be lighter, quieter, and more fuel-efficient. Some airlines may begin limited electric or hybrid-electric flights on short regional routes. While fully electric long-haul flights are still years away, 2026 will represent a major step toward eco-conscious aviation.

Passengers may also see carbon-footprint labels on tickets, allowing them to make more informed travel choices.

Cabin Design Will Focus on Comfort and Personal Space

The days of one-size-fits-all cabin layouts are fading. In 2026, aircraft interiors will prioritize ergonomics, hygiene, and personalization.

Seats will feature better lumbar support, adjustable headrests, and smart cushions that adapt to body movement. Improved air filtration systems will enhance cabin air quality, while antimicrobial materials will become standard on high-touch surfaces.

Economy class may see subtle but meaningful upgrades, while premium cabins will offer more privacy through sliding doors and quieter spaces—even on mid-range flights.

In-Flight Entertainment Will Be Personalized

Seatback screens will no longer be the primary entertainment source. Instead, airlines will integrate personal device streaming, allowing passengers to watch content on their own phones, tablets, or laptops.

AI-driven systems will recommend movies, music, and even destination tips based on passenger preferences. High-speed satellite Wi-Fi will become more reliable, enabling video calls, live streaming, and remote work at 35,000 feet.

For business travelers, flights in 2026 may feel more like mobile offices than downtime.

Faster, More Flexible Booking and Pricing

Dynamic pricing powered by AI will allow airlines to offer more personalized fares. Ticket prices may vary not just by demand, but by loyalty status, travel history, and flexibility preferences.

Passengers will also enjoy more modular booking options—paying only for what they need. Want extra legroom but no checked baggage? Prefer flexible dates but basic seating? By 2026, customization will be key.

Health and Wellness Will Matter More

Airlines are paying closer attention to passenger well-being. Expect better cabin lighting to reduce jet lag, healthier in-flight meals, and hydration-focused services on long-haul routes.

Some airlines may introduce quiet zones or wellness-focused seating areas, acknowledging the growing demand for mindful travel experiences.

Conclusion: Flying in 2026 Will Feel Smarter, Not Just Faster

Traveling by plane in 2026 won’t just be about reaching a destination—it will be about how smoothly, responsibly, and comfortably you get there. Technology will reduce friction, sustainability will guide decisions, and personalization will shape every stage of the journey.

While the romance of flying remains, the experience itself is becoming more human-centered. In many ways, the future of air travel isn’t about machines—it’s about making flying work better for people.

As these changes take flight, passengers can expect a journey that feels less like a hassle and more like a seamless part of modern life.

outlet: Minyak Sayur Bekas Dapat Dijadikan Bahan Bakar Penerbangan - Pontianak News
title: Minyak Sayur Bekas Dapat Dijadikan Bahan Bakar Penerbangan - Pontianak News
description:
Pada saat yang sama, industri penerbangan meningkatkan produksi bahan bakar dari bahan baku terbarukan.
Sementara produksi SAF global saat ini diperkirakan sekitar 2 juta ton per tahun, perusahaan-perusahaan besar memperkirakan akan meningkatkan produksi SAF menjadi 500 juta ton pada tahun 2050.
Campuran ini kemudian mengalami perengkahan dan isomerisasi, yang menghasilkan bahan baku yang dapat digunakan untuk memproduksi bahan bakar penerbangan, diesel, dan bensin.
Dengan pendekatan klasik, reaksi dibagi menjadi dua tahap: oksigen dihilangkan untuk membentuk alkana normal, setelah itu sifat kinerja bahan bakar ditingkatkan.
Baca Juga: Pastikan Perayaan Natal Aman dan Kondusif, Kapolres Ketapang Bersama Forkopimda Gelar Patroli Bersama Di masa depan, solusi-solusi ini dapat menyederhanakan produksi bahan bakar penerbangan yang ramah lingkungan dan mengurangi biayanya secara signifikan.
text:
Industri penerbangan tetap menjadi sumber utama emisi gas rumah kaca: industri ini melepaskan lebih dari 940 juta ton CO₂ ke atmosfer hanya pada tahun 2024. Pada saat yang sama, industri penerbangan meningkatkan produksi bahan bakar dari bahan baku terbarukan.

Baca Juga: China Berencana Menyimpan Energi Hijau Menggunakan Kendaraan Listrik Dan Unit Elektromagnetik Baru

Meskipun pembakaran SAF juga menghasilkan karbon dioksida, emisi agregat di seluruh rantai produksi (dari bahan baku hingga penggunaan) hampir 80% lebih rendah daripada bahan bakar jet konvensional.

Sementara produksi SAF global saat ini diperkirakan sekitar 2 juta ton per tahun, perusahaan-perusahaan besar memperkirakan akan meningkatkan produksi SAF menjadi 500 juta ton pada tahun 2050.

Minyak nabati bekas pakai dianggap sebagai salah satu bahan baku yang paling mudah diakses dan menarik secara ekonomi untuk SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel). Harganya lebih murah daripada bahan baku minyak bumi; pasar global untuk minyak nabati diperkirakan sekitar $7 miliar.

Baca Juga: Waspadai Upaya- Upaya Provokatif, TNI Amankan Pendemo Bersenjata Api di Lhokseumawe

Minyak ini diproses dengan teknologi HEFA (High-Enhanced Fuel Oil), yang menghilangkan oksigen dari lemak menggunakan hidrogen dan mengubahnya menjadi campuran hidrokarbon.

Campuran ini kemudian mengalami perengkahan dan isomerisasi, yang menghasilkan bahan baku yang dapat digunakan untuk memproduksi bahan bakar penerbangan, diesel, dan bensin.

Terdapat dua pendekatan untuk proses HEFA. Dengan pendekatan klasik, reaksi dibagi menjadi dua tahap: oksigen dihilangkan untuk membentuk alkana normal, setelah itu sifat kinerja bahan bakar ditingkatkan.

Baca Juga: Satu Keluarga Jadi Korban Penganiayaan Pelaku Pencurian, Anak Bungsu Kritis

Pendekatan yang lebih modern dan hemat biaya melibatkan proses satu tahap di mana hidrodeoksigenasi, hidroisomerisasi, dan hidrokraking parsial terjadi secara simultan pada satu katalis. Sistem-sistem inilah yang menjadi fokus penelitian di Institut Katalisis SB RAS.

Para ilmuwan sedang meneliti katalis bifungsional berbasis nikel dan molibdenum yang diaplikasikan pada pembawa yang mengandung zeolit.

Tujuan mereka adalah untuk memahami bagaimana metode persiapan pembawa dan aplikasi komponen aktif memengaruhi efisiensi, selektivitas, dan keandalan katalis.

Baca Juga: Pastikan Perayaan Natal Aman dan Kondusif, Kapolres Ketapang Bersama Forkopimda Gelar Patroli Bersama

Di masa depan, solusi-solusi ini dapat menyederhanakan produksi bahan bakar penerbangan yang ramah lingkungan dan mengurangi biayanya secara signifikan.

title: SAF Growth Slows as Policy Gaps Undermine Aviation's Decarbonisation Push: IATA
description:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has released updated estimates for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production, revealing a mixed picture for aviation’s decarbonisation efforts.
High Costs and Weak Policy Support Stall Momentum IATA has revised its 2025 SAF outlook downward from earlier forecasts, citing insufficient and poorly designed policy support.
“If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park,” said Willie Walsh, IATA’s Director General.
Under the EU’s ReFuelEU Aviation framework, airlines face sharply higher costs amid limited SAF supply and concentrated fuel markets.
Airline SAF Targets Under Pressure The slow expansion of SAF production is already forcing airlines to reconsider their climate commitments.
text:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has released updated estimates for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production, revealing a mixed picture for aviation’s decarbonisation efforts.

Global SAF output is expected to reach 1.9 million tonnes (2.4 billion litres) in 2025, nearly double the 1 million tonnes produced in 2024.

However, growth is projected to slow in 2026, with production rising to just 2.4 million tonnes, highlighting the challenges facing scale-up. Even at these levels, SAF will account for only 0.6% of total jet fuel consumption in 2025, inching up to 0.8% in 2026—far short of what is needed to meaningfully cut aviation emissions.

High Costs and Weak Policy Support Stall Momentum

IATA has revised its 2025 SAF outlook downward from earlier forecasts, citing insufficient and poorly designed policy support. Despite installed production capacity, SAF output has failed to accelerate due to a lack of effective incentives.

At current prices, SAF costs around twice as much as conventional jet fuel, and in markets with mandates, prices can rise to five times higher. For airlines, this translates into an additional USD 3.6 billion in fuel costs in 2025 alone.

“If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park,” said Willie Walsh, IATA’s Director General. “But if the objective is to scale SAF production and decarbonise aviation, then regulators must rethink their approach.”

EU and UK Mandates: Rising Prices, Limited Supply

According to IATA, SAF mandates in Europe and the UK have failed to deliver the intended boost to production and adoption.

Under the EU’s ReFuelEU Aviation framework, airlines face sharply higher costs amid limited SAF supply and concentrated fuel markets. In some cases, airlines are paying up to five times the cost of conventional jet fuel and double the market price of SAF, without guaranteed supply or consistent certification.

Similarly, the UK’s SAF mandate has triggered price spikes, leaving airlines to absorb the financial burden. In total, airlines paid a USD 2.9 billion premium for the limited SAF available in 2025—of which USD 1.4 billion reflects the standard SAF price gap over fossil fuel.

“Europe’s fragmented policies distort markets, slow investment and undermine efforts to scale SAF,” Walsh warned, calling for urgent course correction beyond policy announcements.

Airline SAF Targets Under Pressure

The slow expansion of SAF production is already forcing airlines to reconsider their climate commitments. Many carriers that pledged to use 10% SAF by 2030 may be unable to meet those targets due to supply constraints.

“These commitments were made in good faith,” Walsh said, “but SAF is simply not being produced in sufficient quantities to deliver on that ambition.”

The Risk of Repeating Mistakes with e-SAF

Looking ahead, IATA has cautioned regulators against repeating the same errors as e-SAF mandates approach—scheduled for 2028 in the UK and 2030 in the EU.

E-SAF faces an even steeper cost challenge, with prices potentially up to 12 times higher than conventional jet fuel. Without strong production incentives, IATA warns that supply will fall well short of targets, potentially pushing compliance costs to EUR 29 billion by 2032.

“Current policies are clearly not delivering the desired outcomes,” said Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA’s Senior Vice President for Sustainability and Chief Economist. “Mandates have driven up costs and constrained supply. Repeating the same approach with e-SAF would be a serious mistake.”

A Call for Smarter Incentives

title: SAF Production Growth Rate is Slowing Down, Essential to Correct Course Ahead of e-SAF ...
description:
“SAF production growth fell short of expectations as poorly designed mandates stalled momentum in the fledgling SAF industry.
If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park.
The Negative Effects of EU & UK SAF Mandates Mandates in the EU and UK have failed to accelerate SAF production and adoption: In Europe, ReFuelEU Aviation has sharply increased costs amid limited SAF capacity and oligopolistic supply chains.
The failure to accelerate the expansion of SAF production capacity will cause many airlines to review their own SAF targets.
“Given the low SAF production volumes, it is evident that current policies are not having the desired effect.
text:
The Voice of Chandigarh | Travel Trade Reporter

The International Air Transport Association (IATA) released new estimates for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production showing that:

In 2025, SAF output is expected to reach 1.9 million tonnes (Mt) (2.4 billion liters), double the 1 Mt produced in 2024. However, in 2026, SAF production growth is projected to slow down and reach 2.4 Mt.

SAF production in 2025 represents only 0.6% of total jet fuel consumption, increasing to 0.8% the following year. At current price levels, the SAF premium translates into an additional USD 3.6 billion in fuel costs for the industry in 2025.

The estimated SAF output for 2025 of 1.9 Mt is a downward revision from IATA’s earlier forecasts due to lack of policy support to take full advantage of the installed SAF capacities. SAF prices exceed fossil-based jet fuel by a factor of two, and by up to a factor of five in mandated markets.

“SAF production growth fell short of expectations as poorly designed mandates stalled momentum in the fledgling SAF industry. If the goal of SAF mandates was to slow progress and increase prices, policymakers knocked it out of the park. But if the objective is to increase SAF production to further the decarbonization of aviation, then they need to learn from failure and work with the airline industry to design incentives that will work,” said Willie Walsh, IATA’s Director General.

The Negative Effects of EU & UK SAF Mandates

Mandates in the EU and UK have failed to accelerate SAF production and adoption:

In Europe, ReFuelEU Aviation has sharply increased costs amid limited SAF capacity and oligopolistic supply chains. Fuel suppliers have widened their profit margins to such an extent that airlines pay up to five times more than the price of conventional jet fuel and double the market price of SAF. All this comes without guaranteeing supply or consistent documentation.

The UK’s SAF mandate has triggered price spikes, leaving airlines to absorb the burden.

The cumulative impact of poorly designed policy frameworks is that airlines paid a premium of USD 2.9 billion for the limited 1.9 Mt of SAF available in 2025. Of this, USD 1.4 billion reflects the standard SAF price premium over conventional fuel.

“Europe’s fragmented policies distort markets, slow investment, and undermine efforts to scale SAF production. Europe’s regulators must recognize that its approach is not working and urgently correct course. The recent European Commission STIP announcement is a step forward though it lacks a clear timeline. Actions, not words, are what matter,” said Walsh.

The failure to accelerate the expansion of SAF production capacity will cause many airlines to review their own SAF targets. “Regrettably, many airlines that have committed to use 10% SAF by 2030 will be forced to reevaluate these commitments. SAF is not being produced in sufficient amounts to enable these airlines to achieve their ambition. These commitments were made in good faith but simply cannot be delivered,” said Walsh.

Looking Ahead to e-SAF Mandates

With e-SAF mandates approaching in the UK (2028) and EU (2030), it’s essential not to repeat the policy missteps seen with SAF.

Already, e-SAF faces a much higher cost base, potentially up to 12 times that of conventional jet fuel. Without strong production incentives (as opposed to mandates), supply will fall short of targets. On top of that, compliance costs could escalate to EUR 29 billion by 2032 if targets aren’t met, as seems very likely with the current policy framework.

“Given the low SAF production volumes, it is evident that current policies are not having the desired effect. Faced with such facts, regulators must course-correct, ensure the long-term viability of SAF production, and achieve scale so that costs can come down. Mandates have done just the opposite, and it is outrageous to repeat the same mistakes with e-SAF mandates,” said Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA’s Senior Vice President for Sustainability and Chief Economist.

title: Oxylus Energy – Weekly Recap - TipRanks.com
description:
Oxylus Energy is an early-stage climatetech company developing electrochemical technologies that convert captured CO₂ and water into low-carbon e-methanol and related CO-derived fuels.
This weekly recap highlights the company’s recent visibility gains, industry recognition, and strategic positioning across the carbon capture and utilization (CCU) and e-fuels markets.
The company also highlighted its participation in Newlab’s New Climate Futures event, where it demonstrated its green e-methanol technology as a scalable, low-carbon feedstock for fuels and chemicals.
Beyond event-driven exposure, Oxylus Energy gained third-party validation through its inclusion in Cleantech Group’s “50 to Watch” list, recognizing its CO₂-to-methanol electrolyzer platform designed to produce low-cost, low-carbon methanol under ambient conditions.
Taken together, the week’s developments indicate growing visibility, external validation, and strategic positioning for Oxylus Energy in the CCU and e-fuels space.
text:
Oxylus Energy is an early-stage climatetech company developing electrochemical technologies that convert captured CO₂ and water into low-carbon e-methanol and related CO-derived fuels. This weekly recap highlights the company’s recent visibility gains, industry recognition, and strategic positioning across the carbon capture and utilization (CCU) and e-fuels markets.

Claim 70% Off TipRanks This Holiday Season

Unlock hedge fund-level data and powerful investing tools for smarter, sharper decisions

Stay ahead of the market with the latest news and analysis and maximize your portfolio's potential

During New York Climate Week, Oxylus Energy launched a new corporate website and actively participated in multiple high-profile events, including pitch and demo sessions with Greentown Labs, Activate’s Deep Tech Showcase, and Newlab in Brooklyn. Across these forums, the company showcased its e-methanol platform, emphasizing its role as a low-carbon-intensity, drop-in solution for existing supply chains in maritime fuel, sustainable aviation fuel feedstocks, and specialty chemicals. Oxylus framed these appearances as opportunities to engage with potential partners, customers, and investors, underscoring its focus on business development and market outreach rather than announcing immediate commercial contracts.

The company also highlighted its participation in Newlab’s New Climate Futures event, where it demonstrated its green e-methanol technology as a scalable, low-carbon feedstock for fuels and chemicals. These activities reinforce Oxylus Energy’s efforts to build a network within the climate-tech ecosystem and to position its technology as part of circular and low-carbon fuel solutions for hard-to-abate sectors.

Beyond event-driven exposure, Oxylus Energy gained third-party validation through its inclusion in Cleantech Group’s “50 to Watch” list, recognizing its CO₂-to-methanol electrolyzer platform designed to produce low-cost, low-carbon methanol under ambient conditions. The recognition followed a competitive review by global experts and comes as the company advances toward pilot deployment, a key milestone for de-risking its technology and demonstrating commercial viability.

Oxylus further strengthened its industry credentials by contributing to a World Economic Forum white paper, “Defossilizing Industry: Considerations for Scaling-Up Carbon Capture and Utilization Pathways.” The report highlights the potential for carbon utilization to convert up to 27 gigatonnes of CO₂ annually into value-added products by 2050, representing an estimated $4.4 trillion market. Oxylus’s participation aligns it with the emerging CCU value chain and underscores the scale of the addressable market it aims to serve.

Taken together, the week’s developments indicate growing visibility, external validation, and strategic positioning for Oxylus Energy in the CCU and e-fuels space. While no new financial metrics, contracts, or deployment timelines were disclosed, the company’s progress toward pilot deployment, combined with increased industry recognition and engagement, could support future partnerships and funding as it works to commercialize its low-carbon methanol technology.

title: How 2025 Transformed Travel: The Green Revolution Every Tourist Needs to Know About!
description:
In 2025, travel underwent a significant transformation.
In 2025, the mindset surrounding travel began to change quietly but significantly.
This article highlights how greener travel practices have emerged as the new norm in 2025 and the pivotal changes that marked this shift toward sustainable travel.
Slow Travel: A Key Trend of 2025 One of the most significant changes in 2025 was the rise of slow travel.
Conclusion: Sustainable Travel is Here to Stay In 2025, the travel industry made significant strides toward sustainability, with greener choices becoming the norm rather than the exception.
text:
In 2025, travel underwent a significant transformation. While people still sought holidays, new experiences, and memorable photos, there was a noticeable shift in the way travelers approached their trips. As the world faced increasingly severe climate events like heatwaves and floods, travelers began to prioritize sustainability over convenience. Climate awareness grew louder, and more people began to consider the environmental impact of their travel choices. What once was a buzzword, sustainability became a deciding factor for travelers when booking flights, choosing accommodations, and planning their activities.

In 2025, the mindset surrounding travel began to change quietly but significantly. The conversation shifted from where should I go to how can I travel responsibly? This article highlights how greener travel practices have emerged as the new norm in 2025 and the pivotal changes that marked this shift toward sustainable travel.

The Personal Shift: Why Travelers Began to Care More

In 2025, climate conversations felt more personal than ever before. Global environmental changes, including heatwaves, floods, and unpredictable weather, made it clear how much human activities—including tourism—affect the planet. Reports from organizations like the UN World Tourism Organization and the World Economic Forum highlighted the tourism sector’s carbon footprint, and this led many travelers to pay attention.

Rather than simply asking where should I go, travelers increasingly began to question, how can I travel responsibly? This question signified a turning point in the travel industry. It marked the moment when conscious travel became mainstream, no longer confined to niche eco-travel groups. More people started considering their travel choices and how they could reduce their environmental impact.

Slow Travel: A Key Trend of 2025

One of the most significant changes in 2025 was the rise of slow travel. Travelers, instead of rushing through several cities in a short period, began opting for longer stays in one destination. Slow travel emphasizes quality experiences over quantity, and it allows travelers to better understand and immerse themselves in local culture and nature.

This trend was largely driven by the increasing desire to minimize carbon footprints and enjoy meaningful experiences without the haste of ticking off items on a travel list. As part of this shift, train journeys became especially popular, particularly in Europe and parts of Asia. Trains are known for their lower emissions compared to flights, and they also offer scenic views, making the journey itself part of the travel experience.

Night trains and long-distance rail travel were marketed as experiences rather than compromises, and many travelers embraced this sustainable option for both leisure and transportation. Studies from the European Environment Agency consistently show that train travel produces far fewer emissions than flying, and in 2025, more people began to listen and incorporate this sustainable choice into their travels.

Hotels Going Beyond Towel Reuse: Sustainability in Accommodations

In 2025, sustainable hotels began to move past the basic “reuse your towel” sign. Eco-certifications like Green Key and LEED became more prominent, and hotels made them front and center in their marketing. The trend toward sustainability led to refillable toiletry stations replacing tiny plastic shampoo bottles, and hotels worked to reduce single-use plastics wherever possible.

Boutique accommodations embraced local sourcing, from furniture made by local artisans to farm-to-table menus that emphasized fresh, locally grown produce. These small changes helped reduce waste, lowered the carbon footprint of travel, and supported local communities. In 2025, travelers increasingly chose accommodations based on their environmental practices, ensuring their stays aligned with their values of sustainability and responsible travel.

Flights Getting Cleaner: Aviation’s Shift Toward Sustainability

Aviation is one of the largest contributors to travel-related emissions, but 2025 saw significant strides in making air travel more sustainable. Many airlines began to incorporate Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) into their operations, which can significantly reduce carbon emissions compared to traditional jet fuel.

Reports from the International Air Transport Association (IATA) and other industry leaders show that airlines also invested in fuel-efficient aircraft that burn less fuel per passenger. This shift was complemented by the increased availability of carbon offset programs, which encouraged travelers to take responsibility for their emissions by contributing to forest restoration and renewable energy projects. Travelers were given the opportunity to offset their flight’s emissions at the time of booking, increasing awareness of the true cost of flying.

Community-Based Travel Gains Popularity

Community-based travel became a major trend in 2025 as travelers sought out more authentic experiences that benefited local communities. Rather than staying in large hotel chains, more travelers opted for homestays, local tours, and experiences run by locals. According to data from Booking.com and Airbnb, searches for accommodations that benefited local communities saw significant growth. This form of tourism helped ensure that money stayed within communities, traditions were respected, and tourism was less extractive and more meaningful.

By choosing local businesses, travelers contributed directly to the well-being of the communities they visited, helping to sustain cultural heritage and support the local economy. This form of travel, which places an emphasis on cultural exchange and community support, became increasingly important in 2025.

Technology Helping Travelers Make Greener Choices

In 2025, technology played a critical role in helping travelers make more informed choices about their trips. Many travel platforms and apps provided carbon impact labels for flights and accommodations, allowing travelers to compare the environmental footprint of their options. Apps also made it easier for travelers to find sustainable hotels, public transport routes, and low-impact activities.

These platforms provided data-backed transparency, empowering travelers to make responsible decisions without feeling overwhelmed. With the rise of eco-consciousness in the travel sector, these tools helped travelers take action toward more sustainable journeys.

Conclusion: Sustainable Travel is Here to Stay

In 2025, the travel industry made significant strides toward sustainability, with greener choices becoming the norm rather than the exception. From slow travel and sustainable accommodations to cleaner flights and community-based tourism, travelers and industry leaders alike embraced the idea that tourism must coexist with nature and local cultures.

The China E-Fuel market is rapidly expanding and a strategically very important sector in China, encompassing SAFs (sustainable aviation fuels), biodiesel, bio methanol, and other renewable fuels. This market is now a days evolving from traditional fossil-based fuel production to advanced biofuel technologies and high-efficiency renewable energy solutions. It is driven by the growing domestic energy demand, stringent government policies on carbon reduction, and the supportive incentives for green energy adoption. In addition, the market is marked by intense competition among domestic leaders and international players, innovation in feedstock utilization, and large-scale investments in sustainable fuel infrastructure, all within China’s unique regulatory and economic landscapeAccording to government data, China’s renewable fuel initiativesled by the National Energy Administration (NEA) and the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE) are focused on the large-scale adoption of sustainable aviation fuels (SAFs), biodiesel, and bio-methanol. With more than 2 million tons of SAF capacity already built and 4.48 million tons under development, supportive policies and subsidies are accelerating market growth, reducing reliance on fossil fuels, and fostering domestic innovation.

The China e-fuel market presents significant growth potential, driven by rising energy demand, ambitious carbon-reduction targets, and advanced technologies such as synthetic biology, AI-driven process optimization, and renewable feedstock utilization. These factors are creating strong opportunities across SAFs, biodiesel, and bio-methanol.Key growth areas include large-scale SAF production, robust R&D in biofuel technologies, and the use of AI and big data to enhance process efficiency and yield optimization. Despite cost pressures, government policies and subsidies continue to support market expansion.Rapid growth in sectors such as sustainable aviation fuel and marine biodiesel is being fueled by innovations in feedstock conversion, carbon efficiency, and integrated renewable fuel systems.

Market Dynamics of the China E Fuel Market

The China E-Fuel market is driven by addition to a boom in R&D innovations and cutting-edge technologies like synthetic biology and AI-driven process optimization, the China E-Fuel industry is propelled by the country's ambitious carbon reduction targets, advantageous funding policies, and strong government support. As a result, the industry is changing from producing conventional fossil fuels to becoming a global centre for renewable energy. The adoption of the sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), biodiesel, and biomethanol is being accelerated and the large-scale investment opportunities are being created by the fast-increasing energy demand, environmental restrictions, and strategic initiatives. China is becoming a major leader in the global renewable fuel market thanks to the growing emphasis on feedstock diversity, production efficiency, and integrated renewable fuel systems, which are also encouraging local innovation and drawing international alliances.

The China E Fuel market faces restrain like strict government price limits, issues with intellectual property, disjointed laws, and worries about product quality all limit the China E-Fuel business. Despite the industry's significant development potential, domestic innovation and profitability are being constrained by a lack of talent, geopolitical conflicts, and a dependence on imports for essential components.

The future of China's E fuel is growing in rapid technology advancement, encouraging government regulations, and rising demand for greener energy sources all point to a bright future for China's e-fuel industry. New development prospects are being created by advanced fuel synthesis technologies, AI-enabled production optimization, pilot project approvals, and integration with renewable energy systems. Furthermore, advancements in big data analytics, precise energy management, and smart manufacturing are improving production efficiency, acceptance, and regulatory compliance throughout China's growing E-Fuel ecosystem.

Due to urgent aviation decarbonization, while e-methane is also significant for its integration with existing gas grids.

By End Use

The China E fuel market is divided by end use into transportation, chemicals, power generation, grid-injection. Among these, the transportation segment dominated the share in 2024 and is anticipated to grow at a remarkable CAGR during the forecast period. Due to a large vehicle fleet and significant emissions from the transport sector, creating an urgent need for decarbonization solutions.

title: From Carbon Guilt to Conscious Choices: How Travel Got Greener In 2025 - Times Now
description:
From Carbon Guilt to Conscious Choices: How Travel Got Greener In 2025 (Image credit: Canva) Travel in 2025 came with a very different mindset.
From airlines to hotels to the way travellers planned their trips, travel truly began to think greener.
Slow Travel Took Centre Stage Slow Travel Took Centre Stage (Image credit: Canva) One of the biggest changes was how people travelled, not just where.
Many airlines expanded the use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), which can cut carbon emissions significantly compared to regular jet fuel.
Tech Helped Travellers Make Better Choices Tech Helped Travellers Make Better Choices (Image credit: Canva) Technology quietly supported greener travel in 2025.
text:
From Carbon Guilt to Conscious Choices: How Travel Got Greener In 2025 (Image credit: Canva)

Travel in 2025 came with a very different mindset. People still wanted holidays, photos, and new experiences — but they also wanted cleaner air, lighter footprints, and fewer guilt pangs while booking that flight. Sustainability stopped being a buzzword and quietly became a deciding factor. From airlines to hotels to the way travellers planned their trips, travel truly began to think greener. Here’s how travel slowly changed course in 2025.

Why Travellers Started Caring More

In 2025, climate conversations felt more personal. Heatwaves, floods, and unpredictable weather made people more aware of how travel affects the planet. Reports from organisations like the UN World Tourism Organisation and World Economic Forum highlighted tourism’s carbon footprint, and travellers began paying attention. Instead of asking “Where should I go?”, many people first asked “How can I go responsibly?” This shift marked the beginning of conscious travel becoming mainstream rather than niche.

Slow Travel Took Centre Stage

Slow Travel Took Centre Stage (Image credit: Canva)

One of the biggest changes was how people travelled, not just where. Slow travel became a preferred choice. Instead of rushing through five cities in seven days, travellers stayed longer in one place. Train journeys gained popularity, especially in Europe and parts of Asia. Train journeys offer both lower emissions and scenic routes that travellers loved. Night trains and long-distance rail travel were marketed as experiences rather than compromises. Studies by the European Environment Agency consistently show trains produce far fewer emissions than flights — and travellers finally listened.

Hotels Went Beyond Towel Reuse

In 2025, sustainable hotels moved past the old “reuse your towel” sign. They leaned into eco-certifications like Green Key and LEED, and made those badges front and center for guests. No more tiny plastic shampoo bottles—hotels swapped in refillable toiletry stations and cut down single-use plastics wherever they could. Many boutique stays highlighted local sourcing — from furniture made by local artisans to farm-to-table menus.

Flights Became Cleaner

Flights Became Cleaner (Image credit: Canva)

Aviation has always been a big source of travel-related emissions, but 2025 saw visible efforts to improve. Many airlines expanded the use of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), which can cut carbon emissions significantly compared to regular jet fuel. According to IATA and industry reports, airlines also invested in newer, fuel-efficient aircraft that burn less fuel per passenger. Carbon offset options were no longer hidden at checkout. Travellers were encouraged to offset emissions by supporting forest restoration and renewable energy projects, making people more aware of the real cost of flying.

Community-Based Travel Got Popular

At the same time, community-based travel really took off. More travelers picked homestays over chains, booked tours with local guides, and looked for experiences run by people who actually lived there. Reports from Booking.com and Airbnb show a jump in searches for stays that benefitted locals instead of big chains. This meant money stayed within communities, traditions were respected, and tourism felt less extractive and more meaningful.

Tech Helped Travellers Make Better Choices

Tech Helped Travellers Make Better Choices (Image credit: Canva)

Technology quietly supported greener travel in 2025. Travel platforms showed carbon impact labels for flights and accommodations. Apps helped travellers find sustainable hotels, public transport routes, and low-impact activities. Data-backed transparency made it easier for people to choose responsibly without feeling overwhelmed.

title: Thai Airways Ushers in New Era with First Airbus A321neo Delivery - Travel Radar
description:
Thai Airways International has welcomed its first Airbus A321neo, named “Boworrangsee” (registered HS-TOA), a pivotal step in its fleet modernisation.
Eco-Performance Redefined The new A321neo offers major efficiency gains.
This aligns with Thai Airways’ environmental goals, helping the airline meet stricter aviation regulations.
Locking onto Regional Growth The A321neo’s efficiency gives Thai Airways new network flexibility.
A modern, consistent fleet improves Thai Airways’ competitiveness, and aims to attract more business and leisure travellers with higher service quality.
text:
Thai Airways International has welcomed its first Airbus A321neo, named “Boworrangsee” (registered HS-TOA), a pivotal step in its fleet modernisation. As the first of 32 on order via lessor AerCap, the aircraft signifies the airline’s strategic shift to mainline narrowbody operations. It is scheduled to enter service on the Bangkok-Singapore route from January 22, 2026.

Eco-Performance Redefined

The new A321neo offers major efficiency gains. Its advanced CFM LEAP-1A engines cut fuel use by up to 20%, lowering CO₂ emissions per seat. This directly reduces operating costs on competitive regional routes.

The aircraft also supports sustainable travel. It is certified to use up to 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). This aligns with Thai Airways’ environmental goals, helping the airline meet stricter aviation regulations.

Inside the A321neo: Where Hospitality Meets Design

The new cabin is configured for 175 passengers. It features 16 flat-bed seats in Royal Silk Business Class. This offers a widebody-style experience on regional flights.

Economy Class includes 159 seats with comfort-focused design. They have adjustable headrests and a 110-degree recline, and each passenger gets a personal 4K touchscreen with Bluetooth.

The cabin also includes Airspace XL overhead bins for more storage. Dynamic mood lighting completes the space, blending modern design with Thai motifs.

Locking onto Regional Growth

The A321neo’s efficiency gives Thai Airways new network flexibility. The airline can now better serve busy regional routes across Asia. This market is key for its recovery and growth.

This fleet renewal is a strategic statement. A modern, consistent fleet improves Thai Airways’ competitiveness, and aims to attract more business and leisure travellers with higher service quality.

title: Farm economy is becoming a crisis that weighs on families and communities
description:
The farm economy isn’t something we simply live with anymore; it’s becoming a crisis that weighs on families and communities.
In light of the pain points, this year delivered bright spots worth noting both in Wisconsin Farm Bureau and across Wisconsin agriculture.
Wisconsin Farm Bureau earned national recognition, bringing home the New Horizon Award for Gather Wisconsin and the Pinnacle Award, the highest honor from American Farm Bureau Federation.
The fight to protect livelihoods isn’t just about markets and margins, it’s also about mental health and the well-being of farm families.
Brad Olson is President of the Wisconsin Farm Bureau Federation
text:
Farmers faced a year of tight margins, falling markets and rising costs in 2025. These pressures aren’t just economic; they’re taking a toll on farmer’s mental health, as well. The farm economy isn’t something we simply live with anymore; it’s becoming a crisis that weighs on families and communities. Yet farmers kept moving forward planting, harvesting, advocating and sustaining rural life.

In light of the pain points, this year delivered bright spots worth noting both in Wisconsin Farm Bureau and across Wisconsin agriculture.

Wisconsin Farm Bureau earned national recognition, bringing home the New Horizon Award for Gather Wisconsin and the Pinnacle Award, the highest honor from American Farm Bureau Federation. These achievements reflect the strength of organized agriculture and its ability to connect farmers with consumers and policymakers.

Membership surpassed 53,000 for the first time since 1993. That momentum came from grassroots efforts proving that collective action has an impact.

There were several policy wins for farmers worth noting this year, as well. With the passage of the One Big Beautiful Bill, Dairy Margin Coverage eligibility increased to 6 million pounds, offering better protection for milk producers. A biannual cost survey for cheese processors will improve transparency in make allowance calculations, and reference prices rose to $10.00 for soybeans and $4.10 for corn. Livestock producers secured full reimbursement for predation losses, and the Market Access Program received $400 million to expand global marketing opportunities.

Two major policy wins at the end of this year reinforce the connection between agriculture and everyday life. The Whole Milk for Healthy Kids Act passed with strong bipartisan support, restoring the option for schools to serve whole milk. This change reflects years of advocacy by farmers who know the nutritional value of milk and the importance of giving students access to the products Wisconsin is proud to produce.

Another milestone came recently with the passage of the Pet and Livestock Protection Act in the House. This legislation is an important step toward restoring common-sense wildlife management and providing certainty for rural communities that have lived with the consequences of a growing wolf population for far too long. Both of these measures show what can happen when grassroots voices and legislative action align.

At the state level, the budget supported rural infrastructure, processing capacity, conservation and farmer wellness. The Agricultural Road Improvement Program returned with $150 million for roads and bridges, reinforcing the importance of safe and reliable transportation for farm products.

Grassroots advocacy proved its strength when proposed fee hikes for markets and trucking were rolled back after nearly 600 comments from farmers.

While there is plenty to celebrate, there are still persistent challenges that need to be recognized in farming.

Commodity prices remained under pressure from heavy carryover stocks and weaker export demand. Fertilizer and equipment costs stayed high, and interest rates pushed borrowing costs upward. Analysts estimate U.S. farmers will lose $15 billion selling this year’s corn, with combined crop losses reaching $54 billion over the past three years. These numbers reflect a trend that weighs heavily on farm profitability and long-term sustainability.

Health care coverage continues to be one of the most persistent challenges for farm families. Rising premiums and limited rural provider networks make affordable options hard to find. Many farmers are self-employed, which often means paying for individual plans with high deductibles or going without coverage altogether. In some cases, families rely on off-farm employment just to access insurance, creating added stress and financial strain through the form of daycare expenses and additional farm labor.

These realities highlight the need for health plans tailored to agriculture, which is why Wisconsin Farm Bureau is currently advocating for legislation that would allow us to offer Farm Bureau Health Plans for our members.

The financial strains in farming have also amplified mental health concerns. DATCP’s Farm Center reported record call volumes and doubled its client load in September. While sobering, these figures show progress as more farmers are reaching out for help rather than suffering in silence. To help farmers get acclimated with mental health resources, Wisconsin Farm Bureau’s Farm Neighbors Care Program distributed over 12,000 stickers, wallet cards and wristbands in the past year to remind farmers that support is available and that no one faces these challenges alone.

The coming year will demand resilience and collaboration. Stabilizing trade relationships and expanding domestic markets remain priorities, with opportunities emerging in biofuels and sustainable aviation fuel. Continued engagement with policymakers will be essential to secure fair pricing, sensible regulations and strong safety nets for farmers.

Wisconsin agriculture has proven its strength through adversity, but resilience comes at a cost. The fight to protect livelihoods isn’t just about markets and margins, it’s also about mental health and the well-being of farm families. Every conversation matters. Every check-in matters.

When farmers unite, whether to push back on harmful regulations, advocate for better policies or simply support one another, they do more than survive tough seasons. They build a future where farming is sustainable for both the land and the people who care for it.

The challenges ahead are real, but so is the determination to keep moving forward together.

Brad Olson is President of the Wisconsin Farm Bureau Federation

title: Chelsea FC and Pegasus Airlines announce a multi-year partnership - Travel Radar
description:
On December 23, 2025, Pegasus Airlines was announced as the Official Airline Partner of the famous football club, Chelsea FC.
Why Pegasus Airlines?
After operating for more than two decades, today, Pegasus Airlines serves 158 destinations in 55 countries.
This partnership will harness the strength of Chelsea FC’s global footprint and worldwide fanbase to showcase Pegasus Airlines as it continues its expansion.
The $2.5 million-a-year airline partnership deal was to coincide with Omani flag carrier’s 30th anniversary, and was airline’s first-ever Premier League club partnership.
text:
On December 23, 2025, Pegasus Airlines was announced as the Official Airline Partner of the famous football club, Chelsea FC. This partnership marks a beginning for both the organisations committed to global growth and connection via football or travel.

Why Pegasus Airlines?

After operating for more than two decades, today, Pegasus Airlines serves 158 destinations in 55 countries. Its global expansion is defining a new chapter in Pegasus Airlines’ history as it places an order of 200 new aircraft, together with its recent agreement to acquire Czech Airlines and its subsidiary, Smartwings.

With Pegasus’ continued expansion across borders, Chelsea FC will collaborate to deliver innovative campaigns and experiences for its global supporters and customers.

This partnership will harness the strength of Chelsea FC’s global footprint and worldwide fanbase to showcase Pegasus Airlines as it continues its expansion. Together, the two organisations will collaborate across key international markets, delivering innovative campaigns and experiences for supporters and customers around the world.

Working across key international markets, Oliver Boden, partnership sales director for Chelsea Football Club, said:

Pegasus Airlines’ progress in recent years speaks for itself, their vision to transform the aviation industry and unlock the possibility of travel to so many is inspiring. The expansion of their fleet underlines the scale of their aspirations. We are proud to partner with Pegasus at this exciting time, to support them in the next stage of their journey and build a unique partnership together.”

Marking United Kingdom as an important market for Pegasus Airlines, Onur Dedeköylü, chief commercial Officer of Pegasus Airlines, said:

The United Kingdom is also an important market for us, with services to five destinations and further growth planned. This partnership brings together two brands driven by ambition, energy and connection, and we look forward to working with Chelsea FC to create special campaigns and meaningful experiences for supporters and travellers alike.”

Previous sponsorships

Earlier in 2023, Oman Air was the Official Airline Partner of Chelsea FC. The multi-year partnership ended in less than a year, with no declarations from either party on the termination of this deal. The $2.5 million-a-year airline partnership deal was to coincide with Omani flag carrier’s 30th anniversary, and was airline’s first-ever Premier League club partnership.

title: How India's petroleum sector expanded access, fuels and infrastructure in 2025
description:
During the year, the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas focused on affordable energy access, infrastructure expansion, cleaner fuels and domestic production, aligned with the national priorities of energy access, efficiency, sustainability and security.
More than 12.12 crore free basic safety checks were conducted at customer premises, while 4.65 crore LPG hoses were replaced at discounted rates during the year.
Operational natural gas pipelines increased to 25,429 km by June 2025, with another 10,459 km under execution.
Ethanol blending averaged 19.24 per cent in 2024-25, resulting in cumulative foreign exchange savings exceeding ₹1.55 lakh crore.
Through sustained reforms, infrastructure build-out and clean fuel initiatives, the ministry strengthened energy access and supply resilience during 2025.
text:
New Delhi: With over 10.35 crore LPG beneficiaries, ethanol blending crossing 19 per cent, and the national gas grid extending beyond 25,000 km, 2025 marked a year of scale, reach and reform for India’s petroleum and natural gas sector.

During the year, the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas focused on affordable energy access, infrastructure expansion, cleaner fuels and domestic production, aligned with the national priorities of energy access, efficiency, sustainability and security.

Advt

Ensuring universal access to clean cooking fuel remained central. Under the Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana, beneficiary coverage reached about 10.35 crore households by December 1, 2025. To clear pending applications and move towards saturation, the government approved the release of 25 lakh additional LPG connections in FY 2025-26. The eligibility process was simplified through a single Deprivation Declaration, replacing the earlier multi-point system.

Targeted subsidies of ₹300 per 14.2 kg cylinder for up to nine refills annually for PMUY beneficiaries supported affordability. This translated into rising usage, with average per capita LPG consumption increasing from about three refills in 2019-20 to 4.47 refills in FY 2024-25, and further to a pro-rated 4.85 refills per annum in FY 2025-26.

Subsidy targeting and transparency were strengthened through expanded biometric Aadhaar authentication, covering 71 per cent of PMUY consumers and 62 per cent of non-PMUY consumers by December 2025. A nationwide drive launched in November enabled free mobile-based authentication.

Consumer safety remained a focus. More than 12.12 crore free basic safety checks were conducted at customer premises, while 4.65 crore LPG hoses were replaced at discounted rates during the year.

Fuel retail infrastructure also expanded. Over 90,000 retail outlets were enabled with digital payments, supported by 2.71 lakh POS terminals, while more than 3,200 bowsers improved door-to-door delivery in remote areas. Toilet facilities were ensured at nearly all outlets under the Swachh Bharat Mission.

Advt

Electric mobility saw continued growth, with 8,932 EV charging stations installed under FAME-II and over 18,500 additional chargers set up by oil marketing companies. More than 500 truckers’ wayside amenities were established under the APNA GHAR initiative.

Public sector oil marketing companies progressed on setting up 4,000 Energy Stations between 2024-25 and 2028-29, with 1,064 stations operational by November 2025.

The gas-based economy expanded further. Operational natural gas pipelines increased to 25,429 km by June 2025, with another 10,459 km under execution. About 90 per cent of operational pipelines were brought under the Unified Pipeline Tariff regime. City Gas Distribution expanded to 307 geographical areas, with 1.57 crore PNG domestic connections and over 8,400 CNG stations.

Biofuel initiatives delivered significant outcomes. Ethanol blending averaged 19.24 per cent in 2024-25, resulting in cumulative foreign exchange savings exceeding ₹1.55 lakh crore. Second-generation ethanol plants at Panipat and Numaligarh became operational, while indicative Sustainable Aviation Fuel blending targets were outlined for international flights from 2027 onwards.

Upstream reforms included the enactment of the Oilfields Amendment Act, 2025. Under the Hydrocarbon Exploration Licensing Policy, 172 blocks covering over 3.78 lakh sq km were awarded, with committed investments of about $4.36 billion.

Through sustained reforms, infrastructure build-out and clean fuel initiatives, the ministry strengthened energy access and supply resilience during 2025.

By ,

ETEnergyWorld

title: Researchers uncover promising breakthrough for future airlines and flights: 'Major near-term step'
description:
Sustainable aviation fuel, which the outlet described as "a low-carbon alternative made from feedstocks such as used cooking oil and crops," is not the only way innovators are looking to revamp environmentally costly flights.
"Turning everyday trash into jet fuel could be an innovative but major near-term step toward cleaner aviation.
By converting municipal waste into low-carbon jet fuel that already works in today's engines, we can start cutting emissions immediately, without waiting for future technology."
First, it would reduce air pollution by 80-90% compared with traditional aviation fuel.
"Efficiency could be improved by capturing carbon dioxide or adding green hydrogen, produced with renewable power, during processing," Space Daily stated.
text:
As the booming airline industry looks for ways to reduce its impact on the planet, researchers revealed that sustainable aviation fuel could be produced from municipal solid waste.

The study, published in Nature Sustainability, said such a program could meet 28% of global jet fuel demand and lessen air pollution by 16%, Space Daily reported.

Sustainable aviation fuel, which the outlet described as "a low-carbon alternative made from feedstocks such as used cooking oil and crops," is not the only way innovators are looking to revamp environmentally costly flights. One group is turning back the clock with a propeller design to reduce fuel burn, and another is transforming microalgae into biofuel.

Still, less than 1% of global jet fuel use comes from sustainable fuels, Space Daily noted, adding that aviation accounts for 2.5% of worldwide pollution and that air travel will double by 2040. (Other options are plentiful.)

"Unlike road transport, which is quickly shifting toward electrification, there's no silver-bullet solution for achieving carbon-neutral aviation," first author Jingran Zhang said. "Turning everyday trash into jet fuel could be an innovative but major near-term step toward cleaner aviation. By converting municipal waste into low-carbon jet fuel that already works in today's engines, we can start cutting emissions immediately, without waiting for future technology."

Turning trash into fuel would have major benefits. First, it would reduce air pollution by 80-90% compared with traditional aviation fuel. It would also convert plastic, metal, and other garbage into an important product, replacing the need to store those unwanted goods in landfills or burn them. That would produce clean energy, herald the arrival of zero-waste goals, lessen pollution, and conserve land, according to Space Daily.

One problem with the idea is that only one-third of the trash was converted into fuel due to "gas composition mismatches," the website pointed out. The researchers said adding carbon dioxide or green hydrogen to the mix would boost the effort.

"Efficiency could be improved by capturing carbon dioxide or adding green hydrogen, produced with renewable power, during processing," Space Daily stated.

The economic benefits would include savings for airlines that already gain from government incentives and subsidies that encourage the use of more environmentally friendly fuels. The United States and Europe have said they will greatly reduce aviation pollution by using sustainable fuels, with the latter to move from a 2% share this year to a 70% share by 2050.

"Broad collaboration among governments, fuel producers, airlines, and aircraft manufacturers will be essential to increase production, lower costs, and accelerate aviation's path to net-zero emissions," lead author Michael B. McElroy said.

title: La Cámara de Comercio de San Lorenzo se reunió con directivos de Santa Fe Bio
description:
Este viernes 26 de diciembre , autoridades de la Cámara de Comercio, Industria y Servicios de San Lorenzo y su Zona, junto a representantes de la Fundación Aportar, mantuvieron un encuentro institucional con directivos de Santa Fe Bio, empresa recientemente instalada en el predio de la ex refinería de San Lorenzo.
La reunión contó con la participación de Federico Pucciariello y parte del equipo directivo de la firma, dedicada a la producción y comercialización de biocombustibles de última generación, con especial foco en SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel), un segmento estratégico para la transición energética y el desarrollo industrial sostenible.
Durante el encuentro se intercambió información sobre los proyectos en marcha, el estado actual de las operaciones y las perspectivas de crecimiento previstas para los próximos años.
El diálogo permitió fortalecer vínculos institucionales y analizar posibles acciones de articulación orientadas al desarrollo regional.
Desde la Cámara y la Fundación Aportar destacaron la importancia de acompañar iniciativas que impulsen la llegada de inversiones, promuevan tecnologías sustentables y consoliden un entramado productivo capaz de generar empleo, innovación y competitividad en San Lorenzo y su zona de influencia.
